title: Kenya: Equity CEO Vows to Clip Safaricom Dominance
text:
Kenya: Corruption Is As Plain As Mismatched Wealth and Salaries, Obama Says 
Mwangi expects the new entrant to especially disrupt the mobile money market, controlled 77.4 per cent by Safaricom's globally famous, eight-year old M-Pesa, through free money transfer services within Equity Group network. 
Equitel runs under mobile virtual network operator licence after leasing part of Airtel's 60 per cent dormant spectrum in April last year. 
"I believe five years to come the telecommunications industry will be very different...the industry will now be open and we might have four successful telecoms serving Kenyans, giving ...(them) greater choice and that freedom to make decisions and influence the industry," he said in an interview on Citizen TV on Wednesday evening. 
"The biggest battle will be on innovation, we have to be very creative in what we are offering, prices must be reasonable (and) quality of product must be right." 
Relations between Equity and Safaricom have been frosty since falling out in 2011 over sharing of revenue in the country's first mobile banking innovation, M-Kesho - a May 2010 partnership between them that turned sour less than a year after a colourful launch graced by retired President Mwai Kibaki. 
Mwangi maintained his support for the contentious clause on Fair Competition and Equality of Treatment in the proposed 14 sets of regulations on market dominance by Communications Authority that declares a player with over 50 per cent share dominant. 
The successful Equity Group chief said dominance "has never been good for anybody", adding it hinders innovation and creativity. 
"Most of the dominant companies come to an end within a very short time," he said. "It(dominance) is not good for consumers because essentially goods and products are thrown down the throat of the consumers because they don't have a choice and, freedom of choice is so basic and so central to the esteem of a people." 
Safaricom which controls 68 per cent market share, has vehemently protested at the draft rules that will require it to seek regulatory approval at least 45 days before changing tariffs, while its competitors can vary their rates within a day. 
Adopting the rules, Safaricom CEO Bob Collymore said on July 10, will "unfairly skew the market in favour of an operator (Airtel) who lacks "appetite for investment... distorts free market by discounting value of the market ... and is slow to respond to customer needs". 
Collymore said the proposed regulations favoured Airtel and that it was the Indian firm's "latest silver bullet" after the "past failures" through lower mobile termination rates, number portability and non-exclusivity of M-Pesa agents. Kenya
